events.target_title: panel: Remove panel translucency

note.body:
To fix legibility, the simplest answer would have been to reduce the opacity.

If you keep white text on variably opaque black on top of a white background, the WCAG would say that the contrast should be at least 4.5 (7 is safe).

That means you need to set the black opaqueness to 82% for a 4.5 rating. This is assuming the shell theme uses BLACK (admittedly the best case scenario).

On Ubuntu 18.10 (yaru). The color for opaque is #1D1D1D (not black, but close). The actual readability on a white bg is 2.49 according to https://contrast-ratio.com/#%23A4A4A4-on-white

That means the opacity is set to 63.5% ish (not directly in the code, but the end-result of whatever layers of css there is).

I haven't looked at the code too closely, but even in the best case of using black, the lowest opacity should have been 82% to meet readability standards. Of course text-shadow helps, but not that much!

Some places in the code I've seen rgba of #panel as low as 20% or 35%.

Wouldn't it have been better to test a higher percentage first?

Attaching some examples:

Default Yaru

![image](/uploads/097fb604690d76af85a8524118692ad9/image.png)

Opaque Yaru

![image](/uploads/b3a9ef9acb3c199e02826e108ced1c01/image.png)

Modified 1 default Yaru

![image](/uploads/323b5557fa4edda38bea857dc16c6175/image.png)

Modified 2

![image](/uploads/cbc8899185bf5b6176086193dd807100/image.png)

Mod 2 on busy wallpaper

![image](/uploads/4097fd73e78125d156a6378996c3de9c/image.png)

Default Yaru on busy wallpaper

![image](/uploads/bd1871fabd3ba9278d0586f66defd008/image.png)

Changes `data/theme/gnome-shell.css` line 713ish panel property to rgba(29, 29, 29, .6). Mod1 is 4.47 and Mod2 is 7.1 on WCAG

events.target_title: panel: Remove panel translucency

note.body:
@eric1 If you're okay with blaming the user for picking a bad wallpaper, then, by that logic, why have any backgrounds at all? Dock, top bar, window titlebars, etc. I'm pretty sure what you've showcased is a problem with "mixed" backgrounds and not knowing which color to use. (The word "Drive" is barely readable in the snow.)

Testing this scenario with solid colors on Samsung's One UI, it changes the icons and text to dark grey for readability. The top is an 11.2 & the bottom is a 5.7 on contrast-ratios. Both pass the web content accessibility guidelines of 4.5 (I recall material design aiming for a 7, but they now just reference the W3C's 4.5). https://www.material.io/design/usability/accessibility.html#color-contrast

![Screenshot_20190309-170211_Samsung_Experience_Home](/uploads/a205289bc814656a8e0db3bbe824b4c0/Screenshot_20190309-170211_Samsung_Experience_Home.jpg)

events.target_title: Rotation in Gimp 2.10 is blurrier than in Gimp 2.8

note.body: Just wanted to clarify this bug since it has still not been addressed.  In version 2.8.x and older, when rotating an image less than 90 degrees with the default settings (Cubic interpolation), the image had no noticeable loss in detail.  In the current 2.10.x versions, when rotating an image using default settings (Cubic interpolation), the image is noticeably blurred.  This issue DOES NOT involve the use of Sinc(Lanczos3) and the other interpolation options also give blurry (or jaggy) results.

This is literally not supported by ANY client other than late versions of remmina on Fedora. Please allow no encryption support... and set it by default when using configuring it to listen to secure ssh connections only (loopback ssh).

SEO stuff:
`gsettings set org.gnome.Vino require-encryption false`, Fedora 30, Fedora 29, Wayland, Remmina, RealVNC

events.target_title: Support `None` authentication method

note.body: This seems risky... any user land app with network access could fully control the system, or give control of it to a third party. Imagine a rouge Atom extension that runs a remote ssh tunnel to expose your local vnc port publically. A password with no encryption should still be strongly preferred.

events.target_title: Segmentation fault in xmlTextReaderReadOuterXml on 2.9.9

note.body:
Just note that this is a breaking change from one version to another. Before 2.9.9 it was safe to call this function and you would get NULL. Now it gives a segfault. So it all depends on whether you want to keep backwards compatibility and also provide a safe API that doesn't segfault.

On Crystal's side we already fixed the issue in a similar way to what you proposed.

events.target_title: GOA accounts losing credentials when updated

note.body:
This might be related to what's happening in my case. Really happy to see it;s being worked on.
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/issues/266#note_444142

events.target_title: DNS errors being reported when checking connectivity

note.body:
So, I tried building master at time of writing, and the same problem happens. But I can work around the issue if I add a small delay (3-5 secs) to the execution of geary in `~/.config/autostart/geary-autostart.desktop`.

Seems like it's a "race" between geary getting online, and the wifi actually having been connected. The problem is that it doesn't seem to retry after.

I don't even get a `Retry` option:
![geary-GOA](/uploads/3479c84bcf067bc99035886ee1a2b817/geary-GOA.png)

events.target_title: DNS errors being reported when checking connectivity

note.body: I seems to get that sometimes as well. After the restart of geary where errors don't show, it will sometimes stop getting mail. I found out because I thought it was weird that it was silent for that long. Nothing in the inbox. My phone notified me of the emails.

events.target_title: DNS errors being reported when checking connectivity

note.body: Indeed it seems like the `wip/goa-error-when-disconnected` branch fixes my issue.

events.target_title: Can't use tab in any keyboard shortcut
Can't use tab in any keyboard shortcut

note.body:
Okay, having tab be non-rebindable is not obvious but not a big deal.

The issue is that ctrl+tab and ctrl+shift+tab are also non-rebindable. These key inputs do not toggle dock visibility. Therefore I should be allowed to bind them to a different command.

I've edited the issue to clarify this.

note.body:
6 months on, this is still a big usability issue to me - I have to turn off single window mode or I instinctively reach for ctrl+tab every time I want to change image.

This is the keyboard shortcut for "next tab" in every other tabbed application I use - every browser has that key binding, as does every text editor I've used. It's wild to me that I can't assign this key binding.

I understand the rationale for not being able to unbind "tab -> hide/show docks". However I don't see why "next layer"/"prev layer" should be forcibly bound to ctrl+tab/ctrl+shift+tab, with no option to change it.

note.body:
Hi,

Just the point of view of a power user expressed from usage by mor than 100 blind users of GNU/Linux via my Hypra projetct, one of the contributor of accessibility now:
1. I understand it is not academic, clean, beautiful, but when you say ATK is a pain, be aware it just works. So ok the approach is probably technically not grat, but you cannot say it has been broken forever. It works.
2. You are saying that you have a fiirm position now, as nothing has changed since 2012. Just remember that unlikely assertions, GUIs in free software interests much less persons than any other free techno (big data, cloud, embeeded), or web techno. And among these few persons, accessibility in free software just interests no one. Today people working on it are 2: Joanie, Samuel. And they need to work on assistive techno compatibility with Web, debugging Firefox, Thunderbird, web apps (épads, mail, etc).
The result of such firm position is then what was when GNOME3 arrived: just nothing happens and we loose accessibility. Fortunately MATE saved most blind users, but GNOM3 stays unusable by many beginners blind users due to a fundamental incompatible approach. So such firm behavior did generate nothing more than excluding definitely users. I was said that free software had an ethical point of view beyond the technical approach. Maybe accesibility is just so boring.
3. I understand that Wayland compositor should handle keyboard events. But again, 2 persons in the world about accessibility. And devs saying "well let us do what is fun for us, debug accessibility for you". But wayland is much less documented than Wayland. No one knows to implement the thing. And how.
4. Just for companies behind Xorg and Gnome development, be aware that any inaccessible system as we experience today will just make users go to other OSes much more accessible, Apple or Microsoft ones. Maybe we do not care, just let's be awar of it.
5. No one wants no longer invest money in this. Who could help us carrying a crowd funding then? What foundation may do it? Or company? If devs say, "we are fed up, stop accessibility", companies say "no investment", accessibility helpers have work to fix things for now (Firefox, Libreoffice, remaining bugs in GTK etc), Wayland says "not a priority", what is the solution? At least GNOME project or Xorg foundation should help for a crowd funding to enable Joanie or Samuel via some company to spend time on this (a verly long time as Wayland devs dont help for it). Your solution requires an impossible dialog so far between accessibility and Wayland teams. It is a priority for no one: accessibility teams need designers of these tools, designers don't answer, nothing moves. So dont think your reply "lets be firm to make person move" work, such firmness just breaks everything, nothing more.

To sum up, before being firm, just lets find a financial solution via our free softwar actors (I dont believe any volonteer solution in accessibility today). And being firm will ot make it come. And I dont understand firmness except if you show that here are side-effects of such implementation, so far the only effects are on accessibility.

Regards,

events.target_title: key events are not reported to accessibility layer any more in gtk4

note.body:
> No, it doesn't. I have repeatedly seen comments on the internet from users of assistive technologies who have said that using Linux is so terrible that they switched to other operating systems (usually Apple) even though they want to use Linux and tried really hard but it was just not worth it.

Do you know why? Because people try GNOME3 and this desktop has been, yes, completely a pain since 2013 and discouraged many people who tried it. Because the switch was forced, firm, to "make people do things", and nothing happent. The feedbacks you mention are exactly what I said in my 2nd point. Personally I switched to Unity 2D, then Mate as usable solutions.

Fortunately, some distros are bout deciding that when the installer detects a braille keyboard, a display layout for low-vision persons or a speech synthetiser enabled, it will install MATE. And when people use this desktop, amazingly, they are happy. Users on mailing list orca or Hypra can confirm.

Discouraged people are GNOME3 users, yes, due to firm decisions, a completely exclusive vision of beginners or "not regular users". Not all the Linux users.


> And among these few persons, accessibility in free software just interests no one.

> This is a point I have been making, too. The scope for assistive technologies is way too big for the amount of people working on it. We don't need a highly complex abstract IPC mechanism with 3 different public APIs and stability guarantees over decades when all we use it for is making Orca read a line of text.

> The end result is that maintenance of the existing code takes way too much time and no progress happens.

I can understand this point. But unlikely GNOME3 with catastrophic effects on accessibility you highlighted, we should imagine together a transition phase. Wayland will impose itself, nyway, as it will be adopted, video drivers will be handled by Wayland only, etc. But such transition requires that everybody helps, not only accessibility experts. Hence my proposal of crowd funding via GNOME or Xorg foundations, and involvement of compaies carrying these evolutions. So far, everybody says "we should do", when accessibility experts request help from designers, they get nothing, and as we lack resource, the subject falls. And someday falls a firm decision "disabled people, free software does not concern you, bye". Fredeom yes, if you are physically free. Frustrating. Hence why people have discouraged and precisely, we try to avoid not having accessibility at all anymore, following he effort when our previous contributors were discouraged. Please do not discourage us via same firmness than in the past. Or help yourself, policitally, to make Wayland move. I remembre that all these deep changes are imposed by others, we follow a movement, and without help of people driving the movement.

For othr users and devs who do not want to discourage as well, maybe the current effort to make KDE accessible will ben the new alternative if GTK no longer wants to hear of us.

regards

note.body:
> So after all the effort to reduce the negativity on this thread, we ended with several comments like this.

@infapi00 I proved the need to write it because very grave assertions were written in this thread:
"And I am aware that it has been starved by manpower, but it's so bad now that I would suggest that the best way forward is to remove it and suggest people in need of screen readers switch to a platform that isn't."
"Fwiw, I personally do not care at all about working accessibility support in GTK4."

It is terrible for a person like me and you, I think, who have been fought for free software for a long, defended GTK as the most accessible toolkit, paid for people for contributing to GTK, had dialogs with a lot of people in free software to explain that accessibility is not just an expert case. Really, all these efforts getting this fedback, it is terribly hurting. Sorry. I am sure you share this emotion.

Personally after the 2013 situation, I fought to get things working, going on promoting them, so I really am in the support, but this kind of sentence is really terribly exclusive.


> I don't see how the generic "GNOME 3 sucks, Mate is cool" argument would make upstream Gtk developers to get more interested to help on this issue.

After the reply I did to explain the emotion of the global approach of Benjamin, I tried to stay constructive. And I try to be yet. Hence my idea of a transition, but involving accessibility experts and original devs of wayland, with a support of GNOME team explaining that Wayland should handle such issues, etc.

> Perhaps if people were interested on continue the work on gnome shell accessibility that was done on the early releases, even if it was some little effort, instead of putting all their effort on older desktop, would make the situation of gnome shell accessibility in a better status. Because the fact is that we got positive feedback after the work that we (I?) did on GNOME shell for early releases, and in fact GNOME 3 was the default desktop for some a11y distros for some time. But after I needed to stop to do that, nobody resumed it. Neither gnome shell developers, but more important, neither all that people that approached me (included Hypra developers) and offered to help on improving the desktop accessibility.

Right. Publicly, today, I assert everywhere that GNOME3 is technically accessible and thanks to your efforts. The fact Hypra does not use it rely on other problems, related to the design approach (flexibility in particular), but let us consider this is off-topic. I no longer ay, since 2016 at least, that it does not work. It would not be just regarding your work.

I really do not want to say anything against GNOME3 today. I just say that to avoid the empty situation we experienced and which discouraged people, due to so firmness in technical decisions, we should not do the same with a whole toolkit whose the base works so well. I repeat, GTK users are happy and consider that it is the only accessible toolkit today. GTK is a major tookit in free software and the only really usable in accessibility.

The contributions Hypra proposes today are short-term because we try fixing the problems experienced by our users. To make them happy. For the long-term, we would need a support from a foundation or that upstream devs do a part of it, Wayland did not so far. But Hypra is so small that we cannot work for current regressions in Firefox, Libreoffice, introducing new immediately visible featurs to get new users (and so getting more positive feedbacks than these quoted by Benjamin)), and prepare the long future. To do so, we need help.


I'm done, I don't have the energy to deal with so much negativity level. We have pointed this issue to developers that have more experience with wayland, key events and so on. I hope they will be able to provide a better solution.

I hope too. Nevertheless I also hope that the idea of a transition will be accepted, that this debate will enable Wayland teams to react as we need an iterative work together.

Again, just let's avoid the past mistakes which discouraged and made us loose so much people. And sorry for the negativity, but certain statements cannot let me quite as a blind person. And knowing that Your work, will be destroyed by this kind of decisions is alo an disappointing idea iI think.

Regards

note.body:
Thank you for the reply, Jason.

>  I don't think that this change is a good idea.

> In non-fullscreen mode: maybe it made sense to have an option to hide the toolbar, back when Evince had a toolbar, but hiding the header bar looks weird, like it tried to transition to fullscreen mode and failed. I don't see the value of this when we already have a real fullscreen mode.

I explicitly don't want fullscreen here. 
If it is just a short glance at a document, I don't really care, but once I start reading for longer time, I want the header bar gone while in windowed mode. And I'm not the only one [1].

There are other apps which support hiding header bar (e.g. Nemo) and menu bar (gnome-terminal, Firefox).

It is important for smaller (laptop) screens where the vertical screen space is very limited.

In my Gnome configuration I have gone even further and removed title bars from all windows (as described here [2]) and I haven't missed them even once.

>  In fullscreen mode: this doesn't seem to add much because the toolbar already auto-hides after a delay (at least it's supposed to, it's been acting funny lately), so the <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>H</kbd> shortcut only hides it slightly faster.

It is provided for the sake of consistency. But also it is possible to get the toolbar stuck, ignoring the timeout; this allows to get it unstuck without the mouse. For example, after entering fullscreen mode with <kbd>F11</kbd>, I have to hover mouse on the toolbar and then move it away, only then the timer starts to take effect. I prefer keyboard shortcut here.

>  There is one part of this patch I like: how when you click the search button in fullscreen mode, the toolbar immediately hides instead of waiting for the delay. It looks like the patch is also supposed to do this for the annotations toolbar, but the hiding seems to be unreliable in that case.

To make it reliable for annotation toolbar, have to adjust (skip) the timer, but the proper fix would be to prevent header bar from covering annotation toolbar (but I couldn't figure out how to do it). This was a straightforward fix for the bugs to make the toolbars usable in fullscreen mode until then.

[1] https://askubuntu.com/questions/587095/how-do-i-hide-the-toolbar-in-evince-full-screen-mode

[2] https://joshtronic.com/2017/07/26/hide-title-bars-in-gnome-shell/

events.target_title: assertion failed: (priv->handshake_context) in verify_certificate_cb() at ../tls/gnutls/gtlsconnection-gnutls.c:1949

note.body:
Hello, 

I encounter the same problem some weeks ago except that, in my case, the `g_assert(priv->handshake_context == NULL)` is located in the beginning of `do_implicit_handshake`.

I use libsoup to make HTTPS request with a custom TLS interaction object (to use a TPM for signing a certificate). This use case run on an embedded target with a custom OS build with yocto (https://wiki.yoctoproject.org/wiki/Main_Page)

Below are the interesting software versions:
* libsoup 2.64.2
* glib 2.58.3
* glib-networking 2.60.3
* gnutls 3.6.7
* yocto 2.7 (warrior)

I managed to add traces by patching gtlsconnection-gnutls.c to use systemd journal API (`sd_journal_send`) to emphasize the culprit sequence (hope so):

I am inside `handshake_thread_completed` when g_task_return_boolean (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib-networking/blob/2.60.3/tls/gnutls/gtlsconnection-gnutls.c#L2313) is called.
After this call one `g_tls_connection_gnutls_write` is called (sucessfully) and one `g_tls_connection_gnutls_read` (I must admit that I don't know exactly how these are called)
Inside this read function, `gnutls_record_recv` return GNUTLS_E_REHANDSHAKE and so claim_op is re-called (`goto again`).
Inside `claim_op`, the different conditions make the `do_implicit_handshake` be called (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib-networking/blob/2.60.3/tls/gnutls/gtlsconnection-gnutls.c#L765) with a non null handshake_context, hence the failed assertion.
All the functions mentioned above are running on the same thread (at least my traces with `g_thread_self` return the same id).

Please tell me if you think this is another occurrence of the problem you described or if it is a different things.
I have a running setup which make pretty easy (but not always) to reproduce this issue, so doesn't hesitate to tell me if you need more information/traces/patch , I'm ready to make more tests.

Thanks in advance for your support.

events.target_title: assertion failed: (priv->handshake_context) in verify_certificate_cb() at ../tls/gnutls/gtlsconnection-gnutls.c:1949

note.body:
Thanks to you for answering so quickly and for maintaining software(s) I used daily in my job.

Let me know if I understood correctly your point:

You suggest that `handshake_thread_completed` (and more specifically `g_task_return()` in it) should be sure there will be at least a main context iteration before going further in the processing (that is to say, finishing the function) ? So, what about forcing a main context iteration (via `g_main_context_iteration`) if it possible ? Or forcing a cleanup of the handshake context before the call to any `g_task_return()` in `handshake_thread_completed` ?

Strawman proposal for a new generic allocator interface

note.body:
What was wrong with the GMemVtable approach? If it was the indirection, then this seems even worse than that -- each object storing its allocator will mean it's likely uncached and we'll have a stronger hit. If it's because we call g_malloc from within sinit, then I think we should make an effort to stop doing that. Apps that wanted to integrate with their custom allocators wouldn't get the sinit stuff with this approach either, unless we fix that.

The one thing that's potentially helpful here is having a per-thread heap, since there are some libraries I've used that have terrible multi-thread performance because of system malloc (glsl-optimizer spent all its time blocked in malloc, for instance), but the GAllocator API introduced here doesn't seem fit to solve that problem.

Overall, I don't see anything wrong with GMemVtable, and this seems like an overly complicated replacement API with (gut feeling here) worse performance characteristics.

events.target_title: Strawman proposal for a new generic allocator interface

note.body: Right, that's what I mean by sinit. But doesn't this have the same problem? Any memory allocated inside a constructor won't go through the application's "preferred" allocator. Admittedly a small amount, but have we considered taking allocating constructors back out?

events.target_title: Improvements to CoglJournal

note.body: An even simpler approach compared to this should be checking whether dither is the same as it was previously and not flushing the journal if it didn't change -- nothing should be enabling dither.

events.target_title: Improvements to CoglJournal

note.body:
Ahh, I didn't realize dither was enabled by default (GL enables dither by default, too). Dither only affects non-true-color graphics modes, so 16-bit framebuffer configurations like RGB565, or 8bpp indexed color. I assume that we in theory can run on RGB565, so it makes sense to keep dither enabled in that case, and we might want to keep it on just in case we ever want to run on lower color depth framebuffer modes ever again.

Clearly for any sort of non-color framebuffer data like a G buffer or a pick buffer, dither is wrong for the same reason MSAA is wrong. So tracking dither is probably acceptable.

events.target_title: Improvements to CoglJournal

note.body:
Having read this, and turned the OpenGL part of my brain back on, I realized that at the time of the clear, it's undefined whether there's a depth target being used or not -- we would have to track glDepthMask and make sure that the depth buffer is unused by future draws, there's no way to "detach" the depth buffer from the on-screen, and I forgot that we render the pick buffer to the on-screen (switching to an FBO might be acceptable by now and would prevent us from wrecking the buffer for buffer-age, but we're trying to cut out all GPU rendering anyway)

Clearing all the buffer bits probably also triggers fast paths in the driver too, so let's just make sure to always clear the depth buffer Clutter-side as well, even if it's not used currently.

events.target_title: Improvements to CoglJournal

note.body:
So looking into what's going on, this is a bit goofy. Clutter seems to use a different viewport to carefully position the picked pixel just right in a place where it's unlikely to affect the buffer -- I'm not sure I understand the logic quite yet, but it uses a "dirty pixel" from the buffer's damage history (it seems to me like it would be choosing the pixel that's been most *recently* stamped on. If picking happens at beginning of frame perhaps that's a heuristic for what's most likely to be stamped on again, but my read is probably off, and all parties involved in that code have probably moved on to new lives).

The end result is that the viewport indeed changes between draws. Ultimately, I think this is a bit goofy that we're going to all these lengths to track states that you really don't need for the CPU (which sort of tilts my preference towards !189), but let's do things one at a time.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body:
Keeping 3D transformations in this branch would likely not be too hard. A bit of code, but I could write that if someone needs it.

For the general overview, instead of a list of screen rectangles, we have a list of screen-space trapezoids, which can be represented as four points. If it's worth it, we can consider keeping a list of both, since we expect trapezoids to be used rather seldomly and rectangles are easier to test against. If the current projection transform is orthonormal, use screen rectangles, otherwise use trapezoids.

Get the four trapezoid points by multiplying each point by view-projection and dividing by W and mapping to viewport, standard stuff.

Then, since trapezoids are a convex polygon, that means testing whether a point is inside or outside is now just checking whether the point is inside all four half-spaces created by the edges of the polygon. So just four edge function checks, which is just some multiplication and addition.

If you need me to write a sketch of the trapezoid transformation and hit testing code, or explain the math in more detail, I can do that.

events.target_title: Improvements to CoglJournal

note.body:
I'm a bit confused why the clip is so hard -- these are all orthonormal rectangles (can_be_scissor should be TRUE for the non-window clip entries), so the resulting clip should be the intersection of all clip rectangles.

The cogl journal seems to be going to extreme lengths to compute a bunch of extra stuff (like texture coordinates) for clip rectangles when we should basically fail loudly when these are not simply solid color rectangles.

events.target_title: Improvements to CoglJournal

note.body:
Oh wow, so software clip is being used for the main paint path as well? That's kind of crazy. I would probably use a separate journal for picking, since the situations are totally different.

I'd have to sit down with a copy of the math to figure out why the authors believed that can_software_clip cannot handle window clips. We push a scissor clip basically all the time.

From my read though, I'm confused why we're ever hitting the fast-path, since we'll apparently bail to GPU whenever a WINDOW_RECT (aka scissor clip) is pushed to the stack. Unless somehow we're not hitting that path.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body: That's... ugly. Which matrices are stored on the FB? VP?

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body:
The pick API is a bit bizarre as it's been organically grown over time, especially to include things like the clip stack. Overall, this PR tries to clean up the implementation, but I would go even stronger. Instead of supporting an arbitrarily-sized clip stack, I would limit the pick to a 1x1-sized box. That way, instead of a couple of dynamic array, we only need to support one "best actor" per pick stage.

Thanks for the great contribution though! I wrestled with the GPU picking stuff in a past life, so it's nice to see someone come in and tear it down :) I very much approve of the effort.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body: SRT means "scale rotation translation". There are faster inverse algorithms if the matrices you're using are guaranteed to be SRT (commonly used when computing inverse-transpose normal matrices for bone transforms). I didn't realize that inverses were cached inside each CoglMatrix. That's enough for me not to care.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body: No, the 1x1 isn't a typo. I simply mean that when we pick, we aren't picking a rectangle of arbitrary size, we push something to the clip stack that is 1x1 in size, because all we care about is the actor under the current pixel. So if we make the simplifying assumption that we do not care about picking for arbitrary clip rectangles, but instead only a single pixel, then we can lose the list of actors and clip stack and instead just record the "best" actor for the given pixel.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body:
If your monitor is 1080 pixels wide, then at the leftmost edge, your mouse cursor would have an X of 0, and at the rightmost edge it will be 1079, because there are 1080 pixels between 0 and 1079, inclusively.

So I don't see how x == x2.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body:
> * The cursor does sometimes accelerate to the 1px off screen, partly because it moves with subpixel precision.

If you actually receive a mouse position of 1080, this is a bug.

> * Your suggestion to make the interval on each axis closed at one end and open at the other is mathematically inconsistent. I don't think you would get support from anyone to do that.

No, it's mathematically consistent. Imagine a 4x1 grid of large squares, and let's say that we're using top-left siting. So that means that (0, 0) points to the top left of the left-most square, and (0.5, 0.5) points to the middle of the left-most square. Since (0, 0) "belongs" to the square on the far left, it stands to reason that (1, 0) "belongs" to the square next to it, and so (1.5, 0.5) points to the center of *that* square. To which square does (4, 0) belong to? To say it belongs to the right-most square would make the last square slightly larger, because (3, 0) *also* belongs to it. And if we eventually decide to add a fifth square, then (4, 0) would belong to that instead.

Instead, for the case of 4 squares, (4, 0) is simply out of bounds. It's not valid to ask about (4, 0).

In the case of rendering, the parallel to this is edge rasterization rules. And in general in math, if we have 0...N things inclusive, the size of the set is N+1. And if we have 0...1079, the size of the set (width of the box) is 1080. Note that 1080, the size of the set, is *not* contained within the set itself.

Sorry if this is confusing. I would use a whiteboard if I was in the same room.

events.target_title: System hang when plugging in external monitor

note.body:
Interestingly, the behavior changes if I connect another 1080 60 monitor via DP alongside the 4k 60 monitor via HDMI.

With just the 4k monitor, I observe the following sequence:

0. 4k monitor connected via HDMI
1. Boot machine into fb console
2. Start gnome wayland via this line I found on google `QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland XDG_SESSION_TYPE=wayland exec dbus-run-session gnome-session`
3. **4k Monitor lights up with gnome desktop.**
    * It looks like gnome still thinks it's on a 4k60 mode at this point, even though it's really 4k30
      (hardware can't drive more than that)
    ```
    $ xrandr
    Screen 0: minimum 320 x 200, current 3840 x 2160, maximum 8192 x 8192
    XWAYLAND0 connected 3840x2160+0+0 (normal left inverted right x axis y axis) 940mm x 530mm
       3840x2160     59.96*+
    ```
4. Unplug 4k HDMI
5. Plug back 4k HDMI
6. **4k Monitor does not light up**

With the additional 1080 monitor, only the 1080p monitor lights up on step 3. The 4k monitor remains black. I've attached logs for both scenarios:

* [4konly-drm0xff-journalctl.txt](/uploads/6babe4ee5366e1b6930a97a3dcfa4c4a/4konly-drm0xff-journalctl.txt): I've tagged my actions with `** Start Gnome **`, `** UNPLUG 4k **`, and `** HOTPLUG 4K **`
* [4k-1080-drm0xff-journalctl.txt](/uploads/12cb6ed0e03ec4f6739eaf331f943482/4k-1080-drm0xff-journalctl.txt): Only captured gnome starting here, since 4k monitor is blank from the get go.

Sorry for the size, 0xff is quite verbose. Most of them are just vblank interrupts.

manager: don't run autologin display on tty1

events.target_title: Multi-account container [feature request]

note.body:
The usefulness of this feature extends beyond simply having a dedicated container for a particular site. It can also be used to enable multiple simultaneous logins to one site.

In work I am usually logged into at least 4 AWS accounts at any one time, and the multi-account containers feature makes this possible. The feature also allows for creation of a temporary, throwaway container which I use to see logged-out versions of sites that I usually want to be logged into (and don't want to have to log out of). There are lots of variations on this theme.

"Log Out" keyboard shortcut summons the Power Off dialog

note.body:
This occurs also in Gnome 3.30.3.

When in Control Center → Keyboard → Keyboard Shortcuts, a key chord is mapped to the “Log out” action, the expected behaviour is:

* Pressing that key chord should invoke a dialogue that has an option “Log out”, which is automatically selected after a timeout.

* Optionally, other commands can be presented as buttons in the same dialogue (e.g. “Switch User”).

There is no reason we can't *also* have an action that invokes the “Power off” action, but that should be its name, not “Log out”.

note.body: I tried writing a simple program in C to demonstrate the issue, but it didn't work and I was unable to recreate the bug. The original program was in Rust (using gtk-rs), so I'll try my simple program there. If I can recreate the problem in the Rust version I'll close the ticket and open one with gtk-rs.

events.target_title: Gtk-CRITICAL error when using gtk_text_view_scroll_to_mark

note.body:
I was unable to make a simple test case using Gkt-rs that behaved any differently than the C version. I'm starting to suspect threads, but I'm not at all sure how Gtk uses threads internally. However, in the debugger I see the threads: 'sonde' (my application), 'gmain', 'gdbus', 'dconf worker', and 'pool'. Pool is a thread pool I'm using, but I've triple checked and there are no calls to Gtk from any other thread I've created. I'm not sure what is happening with the 'gmain', 'gdbus' and 'dconf worker' threads. 

I put in a static counter to count the number of times it was called and from what thread id. It was always called from the same thread id. It was called as many as 830 times in one case before the error was thrown, and as few as 19 times in another case. Generally an error was thrown more quickly if I move my mouse faster causing more calls in a rapid succession. That's why I'm wondering about threads.

In all cases, if `gtk_widget_get_realized` return `true` then there was no error, only if it returned false. The workaround where I guard my calls to `gtk_text_view_scroll_to_mark` with calls to `gtk_widget_get_realized` seems to work fine. Should this workaround be documented?

I was using the lldb debugger.

events.target_title: Cannot get window-handle of drawingarea natively on Mac OS  and Windows

note.body:
For what its worth I figured out how to get the ctypes working on OSX

```
def get_window_handle_helper(widget):
    window = widget.get_property('window')
    if sys.platform == "darwin":
        ctypes.pythonapi.PyCapsule_GetPointer.restype = ctypes.c_void_p
        ctypes.pythonapi.PyCapsule_GetPointer.argtypes = [ctypes.py_object]
        gpointer = ctypes.pythonapi.PyCapsule_GetPointer(window.__gpointer__, None)
        libgdk = ctypes.CDLL ("libgdk-3.dylib")
        libgdk.gdk_quartz_window_get_nsview.restype = ctypes.c_void_p
        libgdk.gdk_quartz_window_get_nsview.argtypes = [ctypes.c_void_p]
        handle = libgdk.gdk_quartz_window_get_nsview(gpointer)
        return handle
```

I'm still having issues with getting it to layout correctly (the video takes up the WHOLE window instead of being inside the drawing area I passed in), but the call succeeds and the drawing occurs within my window bounds now.

note.body:
OK, it would be too complicated for the getting started page. I didn't build those libraries, I just followed the instructions in "Getting Started".

I did have a look at the [Creating a Development Environment](https://pygobject.readthedocs.io/en/latest/devguide/dev_environ.html#) page, but the instructions for Windows refer to pacman, which I assume is to be run from MSYS2.

I'm under the impression that if I build those libraries inside MSYS2, it will not help me much to install PyGObject in a virtualenv with pip *outside of MSYS2*, because the libraries will not be found.

However, there might be a way for me to specify where pip can find the needed libraries. I suspect with `pip install --install-option <options>` or `pip install --global-option <options>`? I'm unsure which options I need to provide.

Would you know how? Thanks.

events.target_title: pip install PyGObject under a virtual environment on Windows

note.body:
Yes, I did think about creating a virtualenv from MSYS2 to address this issue of compatibility between compilers, but, as you say, it is broken. The issue is [known](https://github.com/msys2/MINGW-packages/issues/5001), but quite recent.

I managed to get a working virtualenv with python.org's Windows python 3.7 and [gvsbuild](https://github.com/wingtk/gvsbuild). It's ugly, but here is a summary of the steps:

* Install python to `C:\Python37`
* Install Visual Studio community
* Install [pylauncher](https://bitbucket.org/vinay.sajip/pylauncher/src)
* Install MSYS2 and git within MSYS2
* From MSYS2, clone gvsbuild to `C:\gtk-build\github\gvsbuild`
* Build GTK3, pycairo and pygobject (or just gtk3-full, I guess) with gvsbuild. Specify at least the following options:
  - `--py-wheel`
  - `--python-dir C:\Python37`
  - `--enable-gi`
  - `-c release`
* You might have to provide other options to specify paths to Visual Studio and MSYS2.
* Once GTK3 is built, copy the whole contents of the release folder (that is: `bin`, `etc`, `include`, `lib`, `libexec`, `python` and `share`) to the virtualenv's `Scripts` directory (where `python.exe` is located).
  - Surely this is not the ideal place for the files, but at least it allows the DLLs, icons in `\share`, etc. to be found.
* Under the python folder are located the python wheel packages for pycairo and pygobject, which are installed in the virtualenv using `pip install`.
* To run my GTK3 app, I had to set the `GI_TYPELIB_PATH` environment variable to `<myvirtualenv>\Scripts\lib\girepository-1.0`, or else an error about the typelibs not being found would be raised.

I wonder, if virtualenv is eventually fixed under MSYS2, would it be possible to build a stand-alone pygobject wheel package, and then use that to install pygobject very easily in any virtualenv created from MSYS2?

I'm no expert on the wheel format or python packaging, but I suppose it could include everything needed (DLLs, typelibs, schemas, icons, etc.) in its .data directory.

events.target_title: Backup fails when looking for libffi.so.6

note.body:
Hey @mterry , so I magically had a bit of an evening to myself tonight and played around with this a bit... here's some information I can provide (sorry, I'm not a Linux developer, coming from Windoze world... but I try ;))

* make

This failed initially on OpenSuse as there's no easy way to install the required dependencies.  Eventually dug them out with some google-fu (I can provide the commands if you want)... yet upon running this, it still blows with the libffi.so.6 error.

* snap

There was nothing wrong with my snapd, I tested other snaps, and all was fine.  Likewise, I removed snapd and reinstalled it... but to no avail.  It won't start on OpenSUSE.  That said, I notice that the snap version of deja-dup *does* actually bundle libffi.so.6

* flatpak

No joy here.  First, it wanted me to download ~2GB of gnome sdk; fair, so I did, but `make` fails miserably here.

* Final solution that worked

I grabbed libffi.so.6 from deja-dup's snap location, and copied it over to my `/usr/lib64` ... and that did the trick.

events.target_title: Backup fails when looking for libffi.so.6

note.body:
I think we can close this... unless you can consider adding an explicit dependency on libffi?

It seems to be working just fine now... the only things I notice; unrelated to this ticket, but merely a general observation and more duplicity related unless you can configure it, are:
- It is slow... IO Read is approximately ~20MB per second... I have NVMes
- IO Writes are even slower... ~10MB/s
- The CPU usage is at an abysmal 1%... surely you can use more juice :)

In short, this backup has been going for 4hr now and is at a mere 33% of the way... in the same time, my Windows backup would've backed up my drives 3 times already.

I wonder if there's anything we can tweak to speed this up?  Maybe we can change the tar.gz size? It's at 25MB per chunk right now... for fast drives and networks, 500MB per chunk is probably a better use of resources.

events.target_title: Crash when using with Sourcetree DIFF in 3.20: Cannot import gi / Cannot import GTK+: The specific module could not be found

note.body:
I used ProcMon to check which DLL is not being found.  It's `libgirepository`. 
Take a look:
![meld-dll-loading-libgirepository](/uploads/c3dbb9adac48b4c8fe7923d29eeb6b6c/meld-dll-loading-libgirepository.png)

Regular DLLs are loaded fine from the `Meld/lib/` folder: `libiconv-2.dll`, `gi._gi.dll`, etc.  
But `libgirepository1.0-1.dll` is searched in the  `Meld` folder, not `Meld/lib` where it actually is.
Because it's not there, other locations in $PATH are being scanned, without success.

What works for me: copy `Meld/lib/libgirepository-1.0-1.dll` to one folder up (next to Meld.exe).

events.target_title: Disable edge-resistance for now, re-enableable via dconf toggle

note.body:
I agree with @chrisjbillington on this issue. The fact is that gnome-shell has an unexpected and distracting feature enabled by default, an no way to disable it.

The argument is that "nobody" wants to disable this is clearly wrong based on the comments and the work put in to acheiving just that. Rather, I haven't seen anyone _asking_ for this behavior in the first place.

While there being a maintanence cost for adding a dconf toggle for this, it's also a maintainence cost for adding this feature in the first place, which I assume is much larger. 

Possible solutions:
- Remove feature altogether
- Disable feature by default and add toggle to enable
- Disable feature by default and require modifier key to enable
- Keep feature as is and add toggle to disable

Not a solution:
- Require modifier key to disable

Justification:
Manual pixel-perfect window placement, without the help of extensions, is a niche use-case required by very few on rare occasions (it applies to only a fraction of times when moving a window). Expecting fluid movements while dragging a window around is an expected feature in all modern desktop-based environments. This is clearly an edge-case, and the behavior should be optional.

Also, how is the modifier-key for the "extreme snapping" feature condfigured and/or documented? Having such features hard-coded and unconfigurable is not a good idea in general.

events.target_title: Disable edge-resistance for now, re-enableable via dconf toggle

note.body:
Looking at other merge requests, I think the commits are supposed to include a link to the merge request, not a bug report. Try putting "https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/merge_requests/455" at the bottom of your commit message.

In addition, @fmuellner mentioned that the commit message itself was lacking justification. For example, add the following to it:

"Add edge-resistance dconf setting controlling whether windows snap to the edges of other window automatically, and set it by default to false.

Edge-resistance gives the appearance of dropped frames and jerky, unsmooth window motion, and is less needed on modern DEs due to the newer edge-snapping functionality.

This change removes the behaviour by default, but allows it to be re-enabled via dconf."

events.target_title: Short high CPU usage bursts

note.body:
I also experience the same issue
* Lollypop version: git, 712022bb
* Operating system: Arch

I tend to leave Lollypop for an extended amount of time (about one week), since I always leave my laptop on except when I need to do a restart. After about 3-4 days in the background the UI becomes very unresponsive, these operations will hang the UI and hog the CPU before the UI becomes responsive again:
* Scrolling (using the mouse wheel / 2 finger gesture). However scrolling by dragging the scrollbar does not hang the UI (but still causes noticeable CPU usage)
* Opening and closing the menus (like the search menu, playback menu, preferences menu)
* Resizing the UI
* Controlling playback via MPRIS is still responsive

I've attached a video demonstrating the hang
[2019-04-24_00-47-10.mkv](/uploads/d26f73d40a015ea7307f4944b88e36d5/2019-04-24_00-47-10.mkv).

note.body:
If developers cannot use the "font-desc" in this way, it should really be in the docs. I read and re-read the widget docs and **nothing** made me think that the behavior that I got is what is expected.

Furthermore, if I were to set a custom font for the GtkSourceMap, it would directly contradict the documentation, which says that the font of the GtkSourceView should match the font of the GtkSourceMap with the exception of the size.

What would be really great if an example of changing the font of the GtkSourceView and GtkSourceMap could be provided in the documentation, even if that only mentions the "preferred" method.

events.target_title: sourceview: add some documentation regarding changing fonts
sourceview: add some documentation regarding changing fonts

note.body:
I do want all textview widget to match that style. What I don't want is the source map to match it.

So, what you are basically saying is that if I want to change the font of all GtkSourceView's but not the GtkSourceMap's, I have to add the style provider to each individual GtkSourceView widget?

Wouldn't it be better to have a CSS tag that would be specific to the GtkSourceMap that would override the value from the 'textview' tag. In applications that open a lot of GtkSourceView's, it would be a pain to deal with each individual widget.

Overlayed widget of GtkOverlay are cut off when used as label in GtkNotebook
Overlayed widget of GtkOverlay are cut off when used as label in GtkNotebook

note.body:
I expected it because it just makes sense to me. The lack on any information about how the overlayed widgets are positioned and sized, let me to conclude that GTK would make an effort to properly display all child widgets. The lack of any API to allow the user to manage the position also lead me to the this natural conclusion.

After some more research and discussion, I've come to realize that size and position management of the overlayed widgets is done through the "get-child-position" signal. Furthermore, for the proper display of the overlayed widgets, the GtkOverlay widget should pretty much always provide a handler for the signal.

If the above is the intended use case, I think that this can be categorized as a documentation bug. Having said that, in my opinion, the documentation of the GtkOverlay widget should get a rather sizable section explaining all this since it's such an important part of the widget's usage.

note.body:
I've had this.  For some reason (win 10, GIMP 2.10.x) selection mode is subtract by default.  

Hold down the shift key while you drag and it will work (enter and double-click will work as described).  See [the docs](https://docs.gimp.org/2.8/en/gimp-using-selections-add.html).

You can see the little + or - next to the cursor when in rectangular select mode.  This is **not** the case when using crop mode.

events.target_title: WIP: Add autofill (using GtkPopover)
WIP: Add autofill (using GtkPopover)

note.body:
I understand this is more than your average contribution. I have to exert some effort to review it myself. One good thing is that the functionality is mostly separated into `lib/autofill` neatly (I think:sweat_smile:) and only the necessary changes are made outside of it (this explains the PR only having additions). And I will try my best to comply with the contribution guides and make it as easy as possible to review the code and even write some docs to explain the flow and design of the code to be reviewed.

The JSC deprecations are unique in the sense that they can span multiple abstractions but they should still be quite manageable since much of the DOM code is local to only some files. I will start working on them next week (about 6 days from now) and hope to finish them in a couple of days.

The deprecations, tests, etc... is the easiest/operational part. The hardest part, IMO, is the product/strategic part (what to include in the first release and more what to not include, opportunity cost, etc...).

For example, multiple addresses/cards may be more important because not having it could force us to have a different data/state in the future and manage it using a sort of migration strategy instead of just starting with it right away using a reasonable structure that would last us for a couple of years in which we can make migrations and other parts even better.

And feel free to include this in the roadmap if you want and I will do whatever I can to get this feature done:smiley:.

events.target_title: WIP: Add autofill (using GtkPopover)

Fix for bug 728313 broke preprocessing on AIX
Fix for bug 728313 broke preprocessing on AIX

note.body:
We haven't update gobject-introspection in awhile. We are doing that now. When we try to build atk-1.28.1 with gobject-introspection-1.54.1, we get the error from the IBM C compiler:
>  xlc_r: 1501-218 (S) file g-ir-cpp-wRb08z.i contains an incorrect file suffix

When we replace the '.i' in giscanner/sourcescanner.py without something more palatable, the preprocessed output is never written to the temporary output file.

For now, we are going to revert to the previous version of the _parse() function. We can live with a local patch. I looked at distutils.unixccompiler and there isn't really an easy way to write to the preprocessed output to a file by capturing stdout.

That would require making a new Smart playlist for every genre, right? I've got 100s of genres and they change somewhat frequently.

events.target_title: Symlinks don't work (regression)
Symlinks don't work (regression)

note.body:
What do you think about following all symlinks, but [normalizing](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/os.path.html#os.path.realpath) all of them before storing in the database? I haven't read the code, so I don't know how difficult that would be, but I think it would resolve all the issues with duplicate files. I'm not sure how it would impact matching cover images to albums though, if a cover image and its associated audio files aren't in the same normalized directory.

(For my particular case, I have no duplicates, and I just want to treat symlinks as regular files. I'm just thinking about this as a way to cover all the use cases.)

-- edit

Actually guys, I am sorry. In my case, the Core Pointer was set to screen. When I changed it to window, as well as the stylus, that fixed it for me. So not a bug in my case. But I think I will leave the comment here, maybe someone made the same mistake as I did. If you don't mind.

Hi everyone,

If I might jump into the discussion: I actually think it is a Wacom/Gimp issue for I am experiencing the same behaviour with Linux Mint and Gimp 2.8.10. No matter if I set the stylus to screen or window, there is always the offset. See what I mean? In the image attached, the mouse pointer is totally correct but it draws somewhere else.

The Wacom is the main screen in my case. This only happens near the corners. In the center, the cursor and the tool are aligned just fine. 

Any support appreciated :)

events.target_title: The export to TIFF "save thumbnail" option doesn't respect the global "No thumbnails" option in Preferences/System Resources/Image Thumbnails
The export to TIFF "save thumbnail" option doesn't respect the global "No thumbnails" option in Preferences/System Resources/Image Thumbnails

note.body:
Ah, a hidden option, I missed that.  An option that produces a "thumbnail" larger than the primary image - how very Hitch-hiker's Guide.

The export to TIFF "save thumbnail" option doesn't respect the global "No thumbnails" option in Preferences/System Resources/Image Thumbnails.  So when exporting a TIFF from a script-fu script you still get a thumbnail.

But at least now I know where it's coming from.  Thanks Massimo.

Pan zoomed document with touchpad
Pan zoomed document with touchpad

note.body:
Thank you very much for your input. As a matter of fact, I indeed found two ways now to pan in a zoomed document with the touchpad.

In Tweak Tool, my touchpad is set to "Mouse Click Emulation", Area, and indeed I can pan after clicking the bottom middle area. There is also a "Fingers" mouse click emulation setting, which would emulate a middle click for three fingers, but that does not work.

Then, in regular "Settings", "Mouse and Touchpad", turning the "Two finger scrolling" on indeed also works to pan in a zoomed document. However, although it functionally is the same, it is clear that another mechanism is involved there: the behaviour is different: rather than getting the "hand" cursor you get after middle-clicking, "Two finger scrolling" instead changes the cursor to an emblem with four arrows, and the cursor stays on the same place while panning.

Selecting the option "Two-finger scrolling" obviously disables the option of Edge scrolling. I find this undesirable for textual documents containing one or more wider landscape pages (e.g. a rotated table in a scientific paper). In that case, scrolling down with two fingers will inevitably also lead to shifting the page sideways. There, I prefer edge scrolling because then I am sure the scrolling will be only vertical.

Anyway, I am salvaged for the time being. I hope that in future versions of Evince, an approach can be implemented that is more discoverable and would work just the same on any computer having a standard keyboard and a one button mouse or touchpad.

events.target_title: Copied filenames prefixed with `x-special/nautilus-clipboard copy file://`

note.body: Could a copy path functionality be build in and bound to Ctrl+Shift+c? That would still be a very acceptable interim solution for people relying on copying paths from nautilus to terminals or in file dialogs. A plugin requiring to reach to the mouse and scanning a menu is a poor substitute, although better than nothing.

events.target_title: Copied filenames prefixed with `x-special/nautilus-clipboard copy file://`

note.body:
Thank you very much! I came up with a similar one-liner using xsel instead:

`echo -n "$NAUTILUS_SCRIPT_SELECTED_FILE_PATHS" | xsel -b -i`.

Note the -n option to `echo`, which avoids outputting a newline at the end.

However, what I really wanted to add here, is that you can assign keyboard shortcuts to nautilus scripts. Create a file `.config/nautilus/scripts-accels` if it does not yet exist, and add the line

`<Control><Shift>c copypath`

to bind the script to <Control><Shift>c in nautilus. Almost as good as the real thing!

events.target_title: Copied filenames prefixed with `x-special/nautilus-clipboard copy file://`
